verification_notes: The quantified claim is too strong and is not supported by the provided context. Rankin-Selberg local zeta integrals are typically defined by convergence only in a right half-plane and then meromorphic continuation, so “finite for all s” is generally false without excluding poles. Likewise, “nonzero for all s” is generally false for fixed test data unless the integral is identically a nonzero constant. The cited inputs (fractional ideal structure, Kirillov nondegeneracy, and a new-vector test-vector assertion) at best suggest existence of nonzero test data for a given pair (Π,π), not a single universal W working for all generic π and all s.

verification_notes: The step is directionally correct but not fully justified as written. The implication “finite and nonzero for all s” to “no zeros/poles on C^\times” is valid only if one identifies z=q^{-s} and uses that q^{-s} ranges over C^\times, and if f(z) is known meromorphic/rational in z. The stronger conclusion f(z)=c z^k requires the additional fact that f is a nonzero rational (or Laurent-rational) function with no zeros/poles on C^\times, so its divisor is supported only at 0,\infty. The claim “since L^{-1} is a polynomial, c q^{-ks} lies in I” is not automatic unless I is explicitly of the form L·R (or at least contains L and is closed under R=C[q^s,q^{-s}] multiplication). The final “by spanning, some V realizes it” depends on the cited spanning result and is fine if that result states surjectivity onto I.
